Sentence: The game of chess is played on an 8x8 grid.
The queen can move in any one straight direction - forward, backward, sideways, or diagonally - as far as possible as long as she does not move through any of her own pieces.
The king can only move one square in any direction - up, down, to the sides, and diagonally.
Each player starts with 16 pieces of which there are 1 king, 1 queen, 2 rooks, 2 knights, 2 bishops, and 8 pawns.
The objective of chess is to checkmate the opponent's king, rendering it unable to escape capture.
If a player has no legal moves and their king is not in check, the game is a draw by stalemate.
If a pawn advances to a square that is occupied by an enemy pawn, the player removes the overtaken pawn from the board.
A player captures an opponent's piece by moving their own piece to the occupied square.
If a pawn reaches the eighth rank, the player can promote it to any other piece.
If the king and a rook of the same color have not moved, and there are no pieces between them, the player can perform castling.
The pawn can only move forward by one square.
If a player's king is in check, they must make a move to get out of check on their turn.
If a pawn makes a double move from its starting position and lands adjacent to an opponent's pawn, the opponent can capture it en passant.
A rook moves horizontally or vertically to an unoccupied square.
The player performs an exchange by capturing an opponent's piece with one of their own pieces.
In the case that the game is timed, the player starts their clock at the start of their turn and stops it after making their move.
The player starts their clock at the start of their turn and stops it after making their move.
If a player's clock runs out before making the winning move, their opponent wins.
The player ought to make a move with the pawn he touches first.
A stalemate is met when a player can not make any legal moves, but his king is also not in check.
All actions need to follow the rules.
